trans-unit.source: During text entry and editing, spell checking informs the user that a word is misspelled by highlighting it with a red squiggle and providing a way for the user to correct the misspelling.
trans-unit.target: During text entry and editing, spell checking informs the user that a word is misspelled by highlighting it with a red squiggle and providing a way for the user to correct the misspelling.

trans-unit.source: Spell checking and text prediction
trans-unit.target: Spell checking and text prediction

trans-unit.source: Guidelines for spell checking
trans-unit.target: Guidelines for spell checking

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]

trans-unit.source: During text entry and editing, spell checking informs the user that a word is misspelled by highlighting it with a red squiggle and provides a way for the user to correct the misspelling.
trans-unit.target: During text entry and editing, spell checking informs the user that a word is misspelled by highlighting it with a red squiggle and provides a way for the user to correct the misspelling.

trans-unit.source: Important APIs
trans-unit.target: Important APIs

trans-unit.source: IsSpellCheckEnabled property (XAML)
trans-unit.target: IsSpellCheckEnabled property (XAML)

trans-unit.source: Recommendations
trans-unit.target: Recommendations

trans-unit.source: Use spell checking to help users as they enter words or sentences into text input controls.
trans-unit.target: Use spell checking to help users as they enter words or sentences into text input controls.

trans-unit.source: Spell checking works with touch, mouse, and keyboard inputs.
trans-unit.target: Spell checking works with touch, mouse, and keyboard inputs.

trans-unit.source: Don't use spell checking when a word is not likely to be in the dictionary or if users wouldn't value spell checking.
trans-unit.target: Don't use spell checking when a word is not likely to be in the dictionary or if users wouldn't value spell checking.

trans-unit.source: For example, don't turn it on for input boxes of passwords, telephone numbers, or names.
trans-unit.target: For example, don't turn it on for input boxes of passwords, telephone numbers, or names.

trans-unit.source: Spell checking is disabled by default for these controls.
trans-unit.target: Spell checking is disabled by default for these controls.

trans-unit.source: Don't disable spell checking just because the current spell checking engine doesn't support your app language.
trans-unit.target: Don't disable spell checking just because the current spell checking engine doesn't support your app language.

trans-unit.source: When the spell checker doesn't support a language, it doesn't do anything, so there's no harm in leaving the option on.
trans-unit.target: When the spell checker doesn't support a language, it doesn't do anything, so there's no harm in leaving the option on.

trans-unit.source: Also, some users might use an Input Method Editor (IME) to enter another language into your app, and that language might be supported.
trans-unit.target: Also, some users might use an Input Method Editor (IME) to enter another language into your app, and that language might be supported.

trans-unit.source: For example, when building a Japanese language app, even though the spell checking engine might not currently recognize that language, don't turn spell checking off.
trans-unit.target: For example, when building a Japanese language app, even though the spell checking engine might not currently recognize that language, don't turn spell checking off.

trans-unit.source: The user may switch to an English IME and type English into the app; if spell checking is enabled, the English will get spell checked.
trans-unit.target: The user may switch to an English IME and type English into the app; if spell checking is enabled, the English will get spell checked.

trans-unit.source: Additional usage guidance
trans-unit.target: Additional usage guidance

trans-unit.source: Windows Store apps provide a built-in spell checker for multiline and single text input boxes, and elements that have their **contentEditable** property set to **true**.
trans-unit.target: Windows Store apps provide a built-in spell checker for multiline and single text input boxes, and elements that have their **contentEditable** property set to **true**.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example of the built-in spell checker:
trans-unit.target: Here's an example of the built-in spell checker:

trans-unit.source: the built-in spell checker
trans-unit.target: the built-in spell checker

trans-unit.source: For more info, see the [**TextBox class**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209683).
trans-unit.target: For more info, see the [**TextBox class**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209683).

trans-unit.source: Use spell checking with text input controls for these two purposes:
trans-unit.target: Use spell checking with text input controls for these two purposes:

trans-unit.source: To auto-correct misspellings
trans-unit.target: To auto-correct misspellings

trans-unit.source: The spell checking engine automatically corrects misspelled words when it's confident about the correction.
trans-unit.target: The spell checking engine automatically corrects misspelled words when it's confident about the correction.

trans-unit.source: For example, the engine automatically changes "teh" to "the."
trans-unit.target: For example, the engine automatically changes "teh" to "the."

trans-unit.source: To show alternate spellings
trans-unit.target: To show alternate spellings

trans-unit.source: When the spell checking engine is not confident about the corrections, it adds a red line under the misspelled word and displays the alternates in a context menu when you tap or right-click the word.
trans-unit.target: When the spell checking engine is not confident about the corrections, it adds a red line under the misspelled word and displays the alternates in a context menu when you tap or right-click the word.

trans-unit.source: For JavaScript controls, spell checking is turned on by default for multi-line text input controls and turned off for single-line controls.
trans-unit.target: For JavaScript controls, spell checking is turned on by default for multi-line text input controls and turned off for single-line controls.

trans-unit.source: You can manually turn it on for single-line controls by setting the control's **spellcheck** property to **true**.
trans-unit.target: You can manually turn it on for single-line controls by setting the control's **spellcheck** property to **true**.

trans-unit.source: You can disable spell checking for a control by setting its **spellcheck** property to **false**.
trans-unit.target: You can disable spell checking for a control by setting its **spellcheck** property to **false**.

trans-unit.source: For XAML TextBox controls, spell checking is turned off by default.
trans-unit.target: For XAML TextBox controls, spell checking is turned off by default.

trans-unit.source: You can turn it on by setting the **IsSpellCheckEnabled** property to **true**.
trans-unit.target: You can turn it on by setting the **IsSpellCheckEnabled** property to **true**.

trans-unit.source: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the [Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=258743).\]
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the [Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=258743).\]
